channel.title: Alcohol – Seven Countries Study
channel.description: Since 1947. The first major study to look at dietary components and patterns and lifestyle as risk factors for cardiovascular disease, over multiple countries and extended periods of time.

item.title: Four lifestyle factors and all-cause mortality
item.dc:creator: SCS
item.description: A healthful diet and lifestyle are related to a low all-cause mortality risk A Mediterranean style diet, a high level of physical activity, non-smoking and moderate alcohol consumption were all associated with a low 10-year risk of all-cause mortality in the European HALE project. A very low all-cause mortality risk was observed in elderly [...]

item.title: Lifestyle factors and depressive symptoms
item.dc:creator: SCS
item.description: In elderly men, mild physical activity and moderate alcohol intake may lower the risk of depressive symptoms.

item.title: Coffee, alcohol, smoking and cognitive decline
item.dc:creator: SCS
item.description: The results suggest that in elderly men without chronic diseases, smoking and drinking were not related to cognitive decline.

item.title: Alcohol, all-cause mortality and long-term survival
item.dc:creator: SCS
item.description: Long-term all-cause mortality was 25% lower in men who drank less than 20 g alcohol per day compared to non-drinkers.

item.title: Wine and cardiovascular disease
item.dc:creator: SCS
item.description: The results suggest that low intake of wine may indeed protect against cardiovascular diseases.

item.title: Alcohol and cardiovascular disease
item.dc:creator: SCS
item.description: Moderate alcohol intake was, compared to no alcohol, associated with a 30% lower mortality from cardiovascular mortality.
